awd_titl_txt: Workshop: Quantum Information on a Chip; October 12-14, 2015 , Universita Degli Studi di Padova, Padua, Italy,
awd_abstract_narration: The goal of the workshop is to map out a roadmap of the evolution and potential breakthroughs in the area of quantum information on a chip for the coming years. It will identify the most promising area of technology where quantum phenomena are expected to play an important role for various applications. An important portion of the workshop will be centered on breakaway sessions to discuss anticipated progress in the areas of quantum communication, sensing, imaging, and computing. Also, breakaway sessions will be focused on required technology advances in single photon sources, integration, atoms/ions-on-a-chip, quantum-dot on-a-chip, and color-centers on-a-chip. A final joint session will summarize the results from the different breakout teams and summarize recommendations for future research. This Workshop will gather some of the leading US and European experts in quantum photonics and facilitate cross-pollination of ideas that will impact future science and technology. This conference will cover a wide range of multidisciplinary topics related to quantum information on a chip. It will open up new directions for research that will leverage out the infrastructure in the area of nanophotonic integration.

por.por_cntn:
NSF Workshop on Quantum Information, Padua, Italy, October 12-14, 2015.

A workshop on “Quantum Information on a Chip”, sponsored by NSF, took place at the Universita Degli Studi di Padova, in Padua, Italy, on October 12-14, 2015. The University is located in Padua, within 1 hour from the airport in Venice.  The workshop involved the participation of about 40 researchers, 20 leading researchers from the USA, and about 20 researchers from Europe working in the area of quantum information and nanophotonics.  The goal of the workshop was to map out a roadmap of the evolution and potential breakthroughs in the area of quantum information on a chip for the coming years. It has identified the most promising area of technology where quantum phenomena are expected to play an important role for various applications. It is expected that future work in the area of quantum information will open up new directions of research that will leverage out the infrastructure in the area of nanophotonic integration that has been put in place by NSF and other government sponsors (i.e. Army, Navy,  Air Force, DARPA, NIST, etc.) over the last 5-10 years. The workshop was co-lead by Prof. Paolo Villoresi from the University of Padua and co-sponsored by the government of Italy and European research organizations. On the USA side, the workshop was organized by Profs. Shaya Fainman (UCSD) and Mario Dagenais (U of Maryland).

Quantum information processing and communications have the potential to address large size computational problems and cybersecurity issues exploiting unique properties of photon states in polarization, frequency, angular momentum, statistics, etc.  So far the realization of quantum information processing systems have been investigated both theoretically and experimentally using free space table-top systems that frequently operate at cryogenic temperatures making them difficult to use for practical applications.  Recent research on generation, manipulation and detection of various photon states, including entangled states, at practically-achievable temperatures has shown the potential to advance quantum information processing paradigms towards practical realization. This workshop focused on quantum devices (e.g., based on color centers, atoms, ions, and quantum dots), advances in novel nanoscale resonant phenomena and engineering of photonic and electronic density of states to advance generation and detection of photon states with the ultimate goal to integrate these devices into quantum circuits on a chip. Superconducting qubits were not part of this workshop.

The 3-day workshop involved a few plenary talks (30 min) to set up the stage of the workshop followed by brief (20 min) presentations of the remaining participants on various topics of their current research in the field. It involved some key talks in the area of quantum communication, quantum imaging, quantum sensing and quantum computing. The key part of the workshop was centered on breakaway sessions to discuss anticipated progress in the areas of quantum communication, sensing, imaging, and computing. Also, breakaway sessions were focused on required technology advances in single photon sources, integration, atoms/ions-on-a-chip, quantum-dot on-a-chip, and color-centers on-a-chip. A final joint session summarized the results from the different breakout teams and established a roadmap for future basic and applied research directions to advance integration of quantum technology meeting the needs of various applications. A detailed report was written on the main conclusions of the workshop and is available from NSF.
